Precision Medicine at Ulster

Our research is answering
the questions of tomorrow
with solutions today.

Can personalised medicine be the healthcare revolution of our century?

Personalised Medicine is when the treatment is customized according to patient’s own characteristics, e.g., using the patient’s cells to produce some cancer vaccine. Stratified medicine is often seen as a synonym for personalised medicine but this term also relates to distinct facets of treatment and care.

It is the use of a medicine that is targeted at a patient sub-population (a proportion of patients, e.g. having a particular disease, age group or disease stage), instead of using one medicine to treat all patients with that disease. Ulster’s biomedical science research encompasses both domains, in both of the Northern Ireland Centre for Stratified Medicine and across the research groups of Biomedical Sciences Research Institute (BMSRI).

"We’re making precision medicine personal. Ulster University researchers have developed new biomarkers, diagnostics and data platforms to better predict disease susceptibility and diagnosis."

Tony Bjourson
Director, Northern Ireland Centre for Stratified Medicine

Competitive
Positioning

Stratified Medicine at Ulster represents the largest Critical Mass of Stratified Medicine Researchers in Northern Ireland (>50 Ulster research staff and 50+ affiliated clinicians), each based at C-TRIC.

Ulster coordinates > £28m of live external grants focused solely on personalised medicine, both within the Northern Ireland Centre for Stratified Medicine (£22m) and across the research groups of the BMSRI.

Ulster is currently undertaking the largest whole genome sequencing initiative in Northern Ireland with Genome Medicine Ireland (GMI).

PhD programme aligned to future industry needs, sponsored by Randox.

Workforce training (undergraduate/postgraduate courses in stratified medicine).

Through our partnership at CTRIC, Ulster is embedded on a major acute hospital site with ready access to patients.

We retain and have access to a patient Biobank with whole genome and rich phenotypic data.

Ulster's Biomedical
Research Themes

Intro summary sentence

READ MORE  

Ulster's Biomedical
Research Themes

The Northern Ireland Centre for Stratified Medicine and C-TRIC has significantly built capability and capacity in stratified medicine research since 2013 and has provided workforce training that strategically aligns with the key international disease and economic development priorities and health challenges facing an aging population. The vision of the Centre is to establish Northern Ireland as a leader in the translation of precision/personalised/stratified medicine, and serve as a magnet for partnerships where discoveries are moved rapidly to commercial and clinical utility in a sustainable way, enhancing health and wellbeing and supporting economic regeneration and wealth. We develop new biomarkers, diagnostic tools and data platforms (from multimodal data -genetic, phenotypic, imaging, and environmental) to better predict disease susceptibility), to better diagnose disease (diagnostic biomarker- better sub-classify disease), assess stage & evolution of disease (prognostic biomarker) and with a strong emphasis on individual patient response to treatment (predictive biomarker) & partner drug development.

The Centre was established in October 2013 by the award of an £11.5 million grant (European Union Regional Development Fund (ERDF) EU Sustainable Competitiveness Programme for NI, Invest NI, the Northern Ireland Public Health Agency (HSC R&D) and Ulster University). The NICM now also incorporates and coordinates the new Centre for Personalised Medicine Clinical Decision Making & Patient Safety (funded by the award of €9M EU Interreg grant in April 2017).

The NICM projects focuses on diseases that each have a shared genetic, lifestyle or dietary determinants, these include: pro-inflammatory and multimorbid conditions including hypertension and associated co-morbidities (such as cardiovascular disease and stroke), Diabetes, Musculoskeletal Health – Motor Neurone Disease (ALS), Inflammatory disease (including rheumatoid arthritis), Mental health (including Alzheimer's disease and dementia) and Cancer (specifically multiple myeloma, prostate cancer).

On the Coleraine Campus, the Diabetes Research Group is focussed on insulin secretion and gene therapy, antidiabetic actions of structurally modified peptides, discovery, action of antidiabetic drugs, mechanisms of pancreatic beta-cell dysfunction and insulin glycation.

The Genome Medicine Group encompasses epigenetics research, prostate cancer, and vision research. In October 2016, in a world first, Ulster scientists at the forefront of the battle against prostate cancer discovered a new combined treatment that could effectively prevent tumour growth, spread and patient relapse. The study was supported by Prostate Cancer UK through a £213,000 grant from the November Foundation and the latest results have now been published by the journal Clinical Cancer Research. The Genomic Medicine Research Group also focus on identifying the mutations which cause ocular surface disorders and in doing so they facilitate improved diagnosis and treatment in the ageing or diseased eye. This work has resulted in discovery of a number of highly disruptive mutations and subsequently development of preclinical models, paving the way for cutting edge therapeutics to be applied to the eye.

NI Centre for Diet and Health has numerous active projects aligned to the prevention of disease, with 5 senior staff members and 4 PhDs focussed on personalised nutrition. For example, studies of folate and the B-vitamin group are focused on the roles of these important nutrients in disease prevention and the interplay between the dietary and genetic factors involved. It is known for example that around 1-in-10 healthy people have a genetic variant ("TT genotype") of the MTHFR gene, which predisposes them to high blood homocysteine concentrations and, more importantly, to higher blood pressure. Such people are estimated to be at 14-21% greater risk of cardiovascular disease compared to those without this factor. Of note, researchers at NICHE hold a patent on the discovery of a novel therapy for treating hypertension in genetically at-risk people. This patent is currently being licensed to one of the world’s largest food ingredient companies.

The Pharmaceutical Science group focussed on the discovery and development of novel therapeutics, imaging, and delivery systems. The theme includes the discovery and development of novel therapeutics such as antimicrobials and anti-cancer agents, the development of luminescent and nanoparticle sensors, bioimaging, photo/sono-dynamic therapy, and polymeric and nanoparticle drug delivery systems.

Ulster Genome
Project

Intro summary sentence

READ MORE  

Ulster Genome
Project

Ulster coordinates the Northern Ireland component of a major all-Ireland Genome Health Commercial Contract with Genomics Medicine Ireland (GMI). GMI is recruiting 10% of the Irish population for whole genome sequencing. GMI is now located in C-TRIC and where Ulster is recruiting the NI component with a pilot project already underway (a £200K contract with very significant expansion planned). Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and other key diseases are being progressed currently as a major CRO initiative with C-TRIC and GMI. The project has recruited 3600 patients out of a target of 7000.

Ulster also contributed to the establishment of, and is linked to, the £3.2m Northern Ireland Genomic Medicine Centre and the UK 100K Genome Project (based at Belfast City Hospital). Ulster is undertaking multimodal omni-omics analyses of data on patients including whole genome sequencing with SNP analyses, proteomics, epigenetics and transcriptomics and microbiome analyses on selected subsets.

Key External
Grants

Intro summary sentence

READ MORE  

Key External
Grants

At CTRIC, Ulster has secured £22M of external grants exclusively focused on Stratified and Personalised Medicine, including the Northern Ireland Centre for Stratified Medicine (£11.5M Oct 2013), which comprises 20 academic research staff, 8 Research associates, 25 PhD Researchers and 45 affiliated GP/NHS clinicians. The Centre for Personalised Medicine, Clinical Decision Making & Patient Safety (€8.6M/£7.5M awarded by EU SEUPB Jan 2017) comprises 14 partner organisations, academic, clinical, business, 10 PhD students and 15 affiliated clinicians. In addition to these large grants Centre staff have secured significant additional external grant income, including from UK Research Councils, EU Horizon 2020, Innovate UK and Invest NI.

£6.2M of BMSRI external grants linked to Personalised Medicine are centred at the Coleraine Campus, including with Avellino on the genetics of glaucoma, with the Northern Ireland Chest Heart & Stroke Association, on the knock out replacement in vivo in inherited corneal dystrophies for MRC, Genome England and the NHS, on KTP programmes funded by Innovate UK and Invest NI and on ocular angiogenesis.

Ulster's Strategic Links
to Industry

Intro summary sentence

READ MORE  

Ulster's Strategic Links
to Industry

Partnerships

C-TRIC enables Ulster to enable in large scale collaborative research partnerships (e.g. Citizens, Patients, Researchers, Pharma sector, Medical Device sector, Health care providers and Government). The Centre is formally recognised by Innovate-UK as ‘enabling infrastructure for Stratified Medicine’.

Avelleno: Ulster University and Avellino Labs, a global leader in genetic science for eye health, have formed a research partnership that could revolutionise personalised treatments for eye diseases around the world. The collaboration will focus on developing state-of-the-art gene therapy treatments for hereditary eye conditions, primarily corneal dystrophies which are a leading cause of blindness worldwide. The research will also investigate the potential for the wider use of the treatments for other eye or ophthalmologic conditions.

In Northern Ireland, BMSRI has collaborated closely with Alamc and Randox, licensing technologies to the latter to enable new diagnostic products for the company.

Commercialisation

Researchers in Pharmacy are currently concluding Ulster’s largest ever IP licensing deal with Grunenthal in Germany to take our patented wound gel to a global marketplace.

Researchers in NICHE have worked closely with Nestle and DSM (on of the world’s largest food ingredient companies) in the development of functional foods and the commercialization of NICHE’s work in the area of folates.

SISAF Ltd is one of Ulster’s most valuable spin out companies, which is currently developing a range of innovative nano-structured silica-based products for drug delivery, skin care and veterinary science. The company is now working with a selection of the world’s largest pharma and veterinary care companies on new products based on its technology. SISAF will shortly announce of Northern Ireland’s largest venture capital rounds to enable business expansion.

Skills Development

Ulster and Randox Healthcare have launched a £1 million skills development initiative to support 10 of the company’s employees through PhD level study. The partnership, which aims to encourage the development of advanced, higher level skills, will enhance Randox’s competitiveness in a key global sector, and further reinforce Ulster University’s position as one of the top universities for biomedical related research impact.

By creating new taught course provision the NI Centre for Stratified Medicine addresses the widely stated need for up-skilling the next generation in genomics and computational biology providing the First Undergraduate BSc Degree in Stratified Medicine (launched in 2013 and scoring 100% in National Student Survey in 2017) and up-skilling the current NHS and industry workforce through the first Postgraduate Cert/Diploma/MSc in Stratified Medic
